book_summary.overall_summary:
Venture Deals demystifies the opaque world of venture capital by teaching founders, investors, and advisers how term sheets, financings, cap tables, and legal mechanics actually work in practice. The authors open with personal anecdotes and historical context (including the classic DEC/AR&D story) to show how a simple offer to invest evolved into the modern multi-page term sheet. From there they frame the negotiation lens around two central forces—economics (who owns what) and control (who makes key decisions)—and use that binary as the organizing principle throughout the book.

The book methodically profiles the ecosystem’s players (entrepreneurs, VCs, angels, syndicates, lawyers, mentors) and explains their incentives, horizons, and typical behaviors so readers can anticipate how deals get structured and negotiated. It then provides a chapter-by-chapter deconstruction of a term sheet: valuation and option pools, liquidation preferences and participation, antidilution formulas, board composition and protective provisions, information and registration rights, and many of the clauses that commonly trip up founders. Interwoven are “Entrepreneur’s Perspective” sidebars that translate legal and financial detail into practical founder counsel.

Beyond priced equity financing, the book explains early-stage alternatives such as convertible debt, SAFEs, and bridge notes—how discounts, valuation caps, maturity, and conversion triggers shape the eventual cap table. It teaches the arithmetic of ownership through a detailed cap‑table worked example so founders understand dilution, post-money vs pre-money effects, and rounding precision. A pragmatic legal chapter warns about recurring hazards—employment practices, entity choice, and the critical 83(b) tax election—so entrepreneurs avoid mistakes that can destroy value.

Finally, the authors step back to situate deal mechanics inside the larger startup ecosystem. Drawing from academic frameworks and their own experience, they present the Boulder Thesis: startup communities succeed when entrepreneurs lead, leaders commit long term, communities are inclusive, and sustained, hands-on activity ties the ecosystem together. The result is a practical handbook that combines legal detail, negotiation strategy, financial modeling, and community-building insight to make readers materially better at raising capital and building startups.
key_themes: Economics vs. Control as the core of every deal
Transparency and education to level the negotiating field
Founders’ upside protection and practical negotiation tactics
Cap table literacy and precise arithmetic drive outcomes
Community and ecosystem building underpin startup success

Be able to read, deconstruct, and negotiate the primary economic and control provisions of a VC term sheet.
Model and interpret cap tables accurately, including the dilution effects of option pools and multiple financings.

Recognize common legal pitfalls (employment agreements, entity choice, 83(b) elections) and implement practical fixes before raising capital.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 5 opens the practical phase of the book by deconstructing a modern venture capital term sheet and reinforcing the central lesson from Chapter 4: virtually everything in a term sheet boils down to two things—economics and control. Building on the Foreword/Preface story of learning VC mechanics and the DEC/AR&D anecdote about the term sheet's evolution, this chapter walks through the common economic provisions (valuation/price, option pool, warrants, liquidation preference, pay-to-play, vesting and exercise periods, dividends, redemption rights, antidilution) and the primary control provisions (board composition, protective provisions, conversion and automatic conversion thresholds). The authors mix plain-language explanation, sample clause language, math for antidilution mechanics, and frequent “Entrepreneur’s Perspective” advice to show why some negotiated items matter and others are often just bargaining theater.

The chapter progresses from high-level framing to actionable negotiation guidance. On the economics side it clarifies how valuation interacts with hidden levers (option pool sizing, warrants, antidilution), explains common antidilution formulas (full ratchet vs. weighted average and broad vs. narrow bases), and flags bridge‑loan customs and dividend/redemption impacts. On the control side it explains typical early and mature board makeups, the use and limits of observers, protective/veto rights, conversion mechanics and the importance of equalizing automatic conversion triggers across series. It closes by warning entrepreneurs to watch for binding conditions precedent that give investors outs, and to focus on preserving alignment and practical leverage rather than getting lost in every lawyer-driven clause.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 reframes the technical lessons of earlier chapters into a practical, founder-focused checklist. Building on the book’s explanation of what a term sheet is and how it concentrates issues of economics and control (Chapters 4–5), the authors warn entrepreneurs about the practical danger of signing or accepting no‑shop clauses before essential deal points—particularly employment terms—are explicitly agreed. The chapter’s main counsel is simple and tactical: if a term sheet (or preliminary agreement) contains a no‑shop, insist that key items (founder roles, compensation, vesting, termination and change‑of‑control treatment, and other material employment/operational terms) be spelled out up front. If a VC refuses to commit to those basics at that stage, that refusal is a red flag.

The chapter also reminds readers that term sheets can contain odd or onerous provisions—“if you can dream it up, it’s probably been done”—so careful reading matters. Signing a term sheet does not automatically mean you have a finished deal; many term sheets are subject to contingencies and additional conditions that can materially change the outcome. In short, this chapter shifts the focus from understanding term sheet mechanics to protecting founder interests during the fragile pre‑closing period by demanding clarity before you give up the ability to shop or negotiate further.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 adopts the entrepreneur’s point of view and reframes the term‑sheet conversation around everyday founder realities: communication, trust, and operational capacity. Building on prior chapters’ technical explanation that term sheets distill down to economics and control, the chapter argues that information rights are not a mere formality or an investor power grab but a practical instrument for running a funded company. Entrepreneurs are urged to run transparently as a norm—if you cannot commit to delivering budgets and financial statements regularly, you should not take on outside capital. Conversely, if you are cautious about sharing, protect disclosures with confidentiality provisions rather than refusing to provide information altogether.

The chapter gives pragmatic guidance: accepting reasonable information rights aligns incentives and reduces friction, while sloppy or inconsistent reporting invites investor intervention and distrust. It recommends that founders anticipate and bake reporting processes into operations before taking investment, so term‑sheet discussions about information rights become implementation details rather than sources of conflict. Finally, the chapter synthesizes the entrepreneur checklist from Chapter 6 with the legal mechanics from Chapters 4–5: treat information rights as part of the control dimension of the term sheet, design minimal but meaningful reporting, and use confidentiality clauses to protect sensitive competitive information when needed.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 adopts the entrepreneur’s vantage point and translates the technicalities of earlier chapters into a single practical north star: protect and maximize upside, especially if the company is headed for an IPO. Building on the book’s prior distillation that term sheets ultimately resolve into economics and control, the chapter urges founders to prioritize economic structures that preserve future public‑market value (pre‑money, liquidation mechanics, participation, conversion and anti‑dilution) and to treat registration rights as secondary tactical items rather than battle‑defining terms. It also reiterates the soft‑skills themes from the entrepreneur’s playbook—clear communication, aligned incentives, and choosing investors who share your exit horizon—because execution capacity and investor alignment are what turn favorable economics into real public returns.

The chapter is pragmatic: if the likely outcome is an IPO, many protections investors ask for (heavy registration rights, aggressive side letters) matter less than the percent of the company the founder retains and the economic lever points that determine upside at liquidity. Founders are encouraged to negotiate against terms that compress their upside (high liquidation multiples, participating preferred, draconian anti‑dilution clauses) and to design financing paths (staged financings, pro‑rata rights, reasonable option pools) that leave room for growth and public valuation. Ultimately the entrepreneur’s perspective reframes dealmaking away from checkbox legalism toward a strategic calculus—who helps you reach an IPO and how the economics and control you give up today translate into value when you’re public.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Chapter 13 shifts from priced equity rounds (explained in prior chapters) to an alternative early-stage financing instrument: convertible debt (notes). Convertible debt is fundamentally a loan that automatically or optionally converts into preferred equity at a later qualified financing, typically at a discounted price to reward early risk. The chapter uses concrete arithmetic (e.g., $500k note with 20% discount converting alongside a $1M Series A) to show how discounts and valuation caps determine the effective conversion price and resulting share counts. It stresses practical entrepreneur tactics: negotiate reasonable conversion time horizons and forced-conversion mechanics, insist on floors rather than ceilings on conversion valuation language, and be careful about disclosing seed terms because caps can be interpreted as price ceilings by future VCs.

The chapter then dives into the key deal terms and risks: valuation caps (to protect seed investors if the next round’s price is frothy), conversion mechanics (qualified financing definition, maturity, minimum raise required, amendment/consent thresholds), the tradeoffs between discounts and warrants (including OID/accounting complications and merger treatment), and the differences between early-stage bridge notes and later-stage bridge financings (where creditor remedies, liquidation prefs, board changes, and pay-to-play can appear). It concludes by presenting SAFEs/KISS as newer synthetic alternatives that avoid debt dynamics (no interest, sometimes no maturity) but carry their own tradeoffs (no maturity leverage, typically no automatic pro-rata rights) and reemphasizes when convertible debt can be helpful—and when it can be dangerous—given cap-table, control, and negotiation considerations covered in prior chapters.

Chapter 14 shifts from negotiating mechanics and financing instruments to practical legal realities founders repeatedly face. It flags a handful of recurring, high-impact legal issues—employment disputes, corporate entity choice, and the 83(b) tax election—that too often become expensive, hard-to-fix problems. The authors stress pragmatism: adopt simple protective practices early (make hires explicitly at-will, consider whether to bake severance into offer letters, and secure good employment counsel) while balancing the trade-offs founders face (e.g., flexibility vs. predictability when predefining severance).

The chapter also clarifies which entity forms suit which fundraising and operational goals: if you plan to raise angel or VC capital, incorporate as a C corporation (multiple stock classes, stock option mechanics, and investor expectations). For companies not seeking VC, S corps or LLCs offer tax advantages but present limitations (LLCs complicate standard employee option grants). Finally, the chapter emphasizes the 83(b) election as a make-or-break tax decision for early equity recipients—file within 30 days or likely lose capital gains treatment—and points entrepreneurs to practical legal resources (notably Bagley & Dauchy) and to maintain at least one reliable employment lawyer.

Chapter 15 steps back from the mechanics of term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and recurring legal issues (covered in Chapters 12–14) to examine the broader geography and social dynamics that enable startup success. It reviews three classical academic frameworks—economic agglomeration (Marshall/Porter/Romer), sociological accounts, and geographic analyses—that explain why innovation concentrates in particular places, then proposes a practical, experience-based alternative: the Boulder Thesis. The Boulder Thesis distills four actionable principles for building vibrant startup communities: entrepreneurs must lead; leaders must commit for the long term (a forward-looking 20-year horizon); communities must be inclusive; and they must sustain continual, hands-on activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter emphasizes that place matters more than ever despite the reach of digital communication: proximity creates shared external inputs (specialized services, talent pools, infrastructure) that reduce fixed costs and accelerate learning. It argues that the long-term view is essential because startup ecosystems cycle through booms and busts; only entrepreneur-led, patiently committed communities will persist across cycles. Finally, it highlights the kinds of repeatable, participatory activities that produce durable engagement—hackathons, meetups, accelerators, startup weekends—and the tolerance for experimentation and failure that allows a community to iterate and mature.

data.overall_summary:
Venture Deals demystifies the opaque world of venture capital by teaching founders, investors, and advisers how term sheets, financings, cap tables, and legal mechanics actually work in practice. The authors open with personal anecdotes and historical context (including the classic DEC/AR&D story) to show how a simple offer to invest evolved into the modern multi-page term sheet. From there they frame the negotiation lens around two central forces—economics (who owns what) and control (who makes key decisions)—and use that binary as the organizing principle throughout the book.

The book methodically profiles the ecosystem’s players (entrepreneurs, VCs, angels, syndicates, lawyers, mentors) and explains their incentives, horizons, and typical behaviors so readers can anticipate how deals get structured and negotiated. It then provides a chapter-by-chapter deconstruction of a term sheet: valuation and option pools, liquidation preferences and participation, antidilution formulas, board composition and protective provisions, information and registration rights, and many of the clauses that commonly trip up founders. Interwoven are “Entrepreneur’s Perspective” sidebars that translate legal and financial detail into practical founder counsel.

Beyond priced equity financing, the book explains early-stage alternatives such as convertible debt, SAFEs, and bridge notes—how discounts, valuation caps, maturity, and conversion triggers shape the eventual cap table. It teaches the arithmetic of ownership through a detailed cap‑table worked example so founders understand dilution, post-money vs pre-money effects, and rounding precision. A pragmatic legal chapter warns about recurring hazards—employment practices, entity choice, and the critical 83(b) tax election—so entrepreneurs avoid mistakes that can destroy value.

Finally, the authors step back to situate deal mechanics inside the larger startup ecosystem. Drawing from academic frameworks and their own experience, they present the Boulder Thesis: startup communities succeed when entrepreneurs lead, leaders commit long term, communities are inclusive, and sustained, hands-on activity ties the ecosystem together. The result is a practical handbook that combines legal detail, negotiation strategy, financial modeling, and community-building insight to make readers materially better at raising capital and building startups.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals

This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture

back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Chapter 13 shifts from priced equity rounds (explained in prior chapters) to an alternative early-stage financing instrument: convertible debt (notes). Convertible debt is fundamentally a loan that automatically or optionally converts into preferred equity at a later qualified financing, typically at a discounted price to reward early risk. The chapter uses concrete arithmetic (e.g., $500k note with 20% discount converting alongside a $1M Series A) to show how discounts and valuation caps determine the effective conversion price and resulting share counts. It stresses practical entrepreneur tactics: negotiate reasonable conversion time horizons and forced-conversion mechanics, insist on floors rather than ceilings on conversion valuation language, and be careful about disclosing seed terms because caps can be interpreted as price ceilings by future VCs.

The chapter then dives into the key deal terms and risks: valuation caps (to protect seed investors if the next round’s price is frothy), conversion mechanics (qualified financing definition, maturity, minimum raise required, amendment/consent thresholds), the tradeoffs between discounts and warrants (including OID/accounting complications and merger treatment), and the differences between early-stage bridge notes and later-stage bridge financings (where creditor remedies, liquidation prefs, board changes, and pay-to-play can appear). It concludes by presenting SAFEs/KISS as newer synthetic alternatives that avoid debt dynamics (no interest, sometimes no maturity) but carry their own tradeoffs (no maturity leverage, typically no automatic pro-rata rights) and reemphasizes when convertible debt can be helpful—and when it can be dangerous—given cap-table, control, and negotiation considerations covered in prior chapters.

Chapter 14 shifts from negotiating mechanics and financing instruments to practical legal realities founders repeatedly face. It flags a handful of recurring, high-impact legal issues—employment disputes, corporate entity choice, and the 83(b) tax election—that too often become expensive, hard-to-fix problems. The authors stress pragmatism: adopt simple protective practices early (make hires explicitly at-will, consider whether to bake severance into offer letters, and secure good employment counsel) while balancing the trade-offs founders face (e.g., flexibility vs. predictability when predefining severance).

The chapter also clarifies which entity forms suit which fundraising and operational goals: if you plan to raise angel or VC capital, incorporate as a C corporation (multiple stock classes, stock option mechanics, and investor expectations). For companies not seeking VC, S corps or LLCs offer tax advantages but present limitations (LLCs complicate standard employee option grants). Finally, the chapter emphasizes the 83(b) election as a make-or-break tax decision for early equity recipients—file within 30 days or likely lose capital gains treatment—and points entrepreneurs to practical legal resources (notably Bagley & Dauchy) and to maintain at least one reliable employment lawyer.

Chapter 15 steps back from the mechanics of term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and recurring legal issues (covered in Chapters 12–14) to examine the broader geography and social dynamics that enable startup success. It reviews three classical academic frameworks—economic agglomeration (Marshall/Porter/Romer), sociological accounts, and geographic analyses—that explain why innovation concentrates in particular places, then proposes a practical, experience-based alternative: the Boulder Thesis. The Boulder Thesis distills four actionable principles for building vibrant startup communities: entrepreneurs must lead; leaders must commit for the long term (a forward-looking 20-year horizon); communities must be inclusive; and they must sustain continual, hands-on activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter emphasizes that place matters more than ever despite the reach of digital communication: proximity creates shared external inputs (specialized services, talent pools, infrastructure) that reduce fixed costs and accelerate learning. It argues that the long-term view is essential because startup ecosystems cycle through booms and busts; only entrepreneur-led, patiently committed communities will persist across cycles. Finally, it highlights the kinds of repeatable, participatory activities that produce durable engagement—hackathons, meetups, accelerators, startup weekends—and the tolerance for experimentation and failure that allows a community to iterate and mature.
